justification: “In all of our studies thus far, risk preferences are assessed in terms of choices between a fixed option … and a risky option …” describing the decisions-from-experience task used to gauge risk preference.

The paper notes that “In decisions from description choices—where odds and outcomes are explicitly stated, people are more risk seeking for losses than gains,” indicating that the description format is the instrument used to measure risk preference.
Participants “were asked to type the first outcome that came to mind for that door, which we termed the ‘first-outcome-reported’ test. This test assessed the availability of each outcome in memory.”

Participants “estimated the percentage of the time that the presented door led to each of the possible outcomes, termed the ‘frequency-judgment’ test,” which was used to assess distortions in remembered outcome frequencies.
